title: 114_hr5561
content: The Act may be cited as the "Max Cleland Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2016". Congress finds that Max Cleland has shown exceptional professionalism and dedication to public service, starting from his time in the Army during the Vietnam War where he rose to the rank of Captain and was awarded a Silver Star for his bravery at the Battle of Khe Sanh in 1968. Captain Joseph Maxwell Cleland, a Battalion Signal Officer in the United States Army, was awarded the Silver Star for gallantry in action during the Vietnam War. He lost both legs and his right arm in battle, undergoing 18 months of rehabilitation at Walter Reed Army Medical Center and VA hospitals in Washington, DC. In 1969, Max Cleland testified before the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs about the challenges faced by returning veterans. He later became the youngest Georgia State senator, passing legislation for accessibility. Cleland then joined the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs in Washington, DC, investigating VA hospitals and servicemember treatment. President Jimmy Carter appointed Cleland as the youngest and first individual to the committee in 1977. Max Cleland, the youngest Vietnam veteran to serve as Administrator of the Veterans Administration, created the "Vet Center" counseling program. He later became Secretary of State of Georgia, implementing the National Voter Registration Act and adding almost 1 million new voters to the rolls. Cleland was then elected to the United States Senate. Max Cleland was elected to the United States Senate in 1996 and chaired the Subcommittee on Personnel of the Committee on Armed Services. He expanded benefits for servicemembers and improved veterans' health care, education, and the environment. After his Senate service, Cleland joined the 9/11 Commission and later served on the Board of Directors of the Export-Import Bank. In 2009, President Obama appointed him Secretary of the American Battle Monuments Commission. Max Cleland, appointed Secretary of the American Battle Monuments Commission by President Obama in 2009, is responsible for commemorating US cemeteries and military memorials abroad. In 2010, Cleland served as chair of the Advisory Committee on Arlington National Cemetery, receiving the Decoration for Distinguished Civilian Service after his tenure. Max Cleland was awarded the Decoration for Distinguished Civilian Service of the Army, the highest honorary award from the Secretary of the Army. He has dedicated almost five decades of his life in service to the United States, overcoming significant challenges along the way. Max Cleland was awarded the Congressional Gold Medal. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of a gold medal to Joseph Maxwell Cleland. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicates in bronze may be struck and sold under regulations set by the Secretary. The sale of duplicate medals will result in funds being deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 4. STATUS OF MEDALS. Medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code and considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code.
